title: SB 1324
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 13957.9 of the Government Code is amended to allow the board to grant reimbursement for outpatient psychiatric, psychological, or mental health counseling expenses incurred by victims of violent crime and their family members, if deemed necessary for successful treatment. Victims of violent crime and their family members may be reimbursed for outpatient mental health counseling expenses. Victims can receive up to $10,000, while family members can receive up to $5,000 for counseling services. Victims of violent crime and their family members may be reimbursed for outpatient mental health counseling expenses. A derivative victim not eligible for reimbursement unless counseling is necessary for treatment. Victims of unlawful sexual intercourse with a minor are eligible for reimbursement, but derivative victims are not eligible for mental health counseling expenses. The board may reimburse victims or derivative victims for outpatient mental health counseling in excess of authorized limits or for inpatient psychiatric, psychological, or other mental health counseling in dire circumstances. Reimbursement for counseling services is only available if provided by approved individuals. The California board may reimburse victims or derivative victims for mental health counseling services provided by authorized individuals. The total award per victim cannot exceed $35,000, but may increase to $70,000 with federal funds. A "service organization for victims of violent crime" is defined as a nonprofit organization with a primary mission to assist victims of violent crime. The California board reimburses victims for mental health counseling services. A "service organization for victims of violent crime" provides programs to victims and their families. Violence peer counseling services offer advice and assistance to victims of violent crime and their families, falling under specific practice acts and not performed in exempt settings. The practice acts specified in sections 4980.01, 4996.14, and 4999.22 of the Business and Professions Code require services to be provided by licensed professionals like psychologists or psychiatrists. A "violence peer counselor" provides supportive peer counseling services for victims of violent crime, with requirements including six months of experience, completion of a training program, and 40 hours of training. The violence peer counselor must complete 40 hours of training on trauma effects, peace-building strategies, PTSD, and case management practices. When providing violence peer counseling services, the counselor must be supervised by a licensed marriage and family therapist, licensed educational psychologist, licensed clinical social worker, or licensed professional clinical counselor employed by the same service organization. The section will be in effect until January 1, 2019, and will be repealed unless a later statute extends the date. No reimbursement is required for this act as it pertains to creating, eliminating, or changing penalties for crimes or infractions.
